content: The Act titled "Nuclear Terrorism Prevention Act of 2006" defines key terms related to nuclear terrorism prevention. The Act titled "Nuclear Terrorism Prevention Act of 2006" defines key terms related to nuclear material protection, design-basis threat, formula quantities of strategic special nuclear material, and the Nuclear Non-Proliferation Treaty. The term "nuclear weapon" is defined as any device utilizing atomic energy for use as a weapon, prototype, or test device. SEC. 3. FINDINGS. Congress finds that the threat of terrorists acquiring and using a nuclear weapon is urgent and poses a significant risk to national and global security. Efforts to secure nuclear stockpiles and prevent nuclear smuggling have made progress, but more actions are necessary to reduce the threat of nuclear terrorism. The White House's 2006 National Strategy for Combating Terrorism highlights the grave danger of weapons of mass destruction in the hands of terrorists. UN Secretary-General Kofi Annan warns that a nuclear terror attack would have devastating consequences on a global scale. UN Security Council Resolution 1540 emphasizes the importance of combating this threat through all available means. The Director General of the International Atomic Energy Agency emphasizes the urgent need to prevent terrorist attacks using nuclear weapons by adopting and enforcing effective laws prohibiting non-state actors from acquiring, developing, or using weapons of mass destruction for terrorist purposes. Sense of Congress on preventing nuclear terrorism. The sense of Congress is that the threat of nuclear terror is the most horrific the United States faces. A comprehensive approach is needed to reduce this danger, including efforts to identify and eliminate terrorist groups seeking nuclear weapons, secure nuclear weapons worldwide, and prevent terrorist efforts to manufacture or transport nuclear explosives. The prevention of a nuclear terrorist attack on the United States should be a top priority. The President should accelerate programs to prevent nuclear terrorism, secure nuclear materials, and combat nuclear smuggling. The International Atomic Energy Agency plays a vital role in coordinating international efforts in this regard. Legislation sponsored by Senators Lugar, Domenici, and Nunn has led to groundbreaking programs to prevent terrorists from obtaining nuclear weapons. The National Security Act of 1947 is amended to include a new section for a senior advisor to the president for the prevention of nuclear terrorism. This is in line with efforts to prevent nuclear terrorism, secure nuclear materials, and combat nuclear smuggling, with the International Atomic Energy Agency playing a key role in coordinating international efforts. Legislation sponsored by Senators Lugar, Domenici, and Nunn has been instrumental in creating programs to prevent terrorists from obtaining nuclear weapons. The National Security Act of 1947 is amended to include a Senior Advisor to the President for the Prevention of Nuclear Terrorism. The advisor is appointed by the President with Senate approval and is responsible for advising on nuclear terrorism matters, formulating prevention policies, and overseeing program implementation strategies. The Senior Advisor to the President for the Prevention of Nuclear Terrorism is responsible for overseeing budget requests, identifying new initiatives, and coordinating US efforts to implement policies related to nuclear terrorism prevention. The advisor can appoint and terminate necessary personnel to fulfill their duties and is a member of the National Security Council. The Senior Advisor to the President for the Prevention of Nuclear Terrorism oversees budget requests, initiates new policies, and coordinates US efforts in nuclear terrorism prevention. They have the authority to appoint and dismiss personnel and are a member of the National Security Council. Additionally, an annual report is required. The President, with the Senior Advisor, submits an annual report to Congress on the security of nuclear materials, including a survey of global facilities and priority sites. The President, with the Senior Advisor, submits an annual report to Congress on the security of nuclear materials, including a survey of global facilities and priority sites. The report includes a plan for securing or removing nuclear weapons and materials at vulnerable sites worldwide, as well as efforts to establish and implement security standards and policies. The report on security standards and policies, as outlined in section 7, may be submitted in classified form but must include a detailed unclassified summary. SEC. 7 outlines the minimum security standard for nuclear weapons and strategic special nuclear materials. The United States policy is to ensure the security and accountability of all nuclear weapons and special nuclear materials. In line with international standards, the President will work towards a global agreement on nuclear security that effectively protects against threats, considers equipment and human limitations, and is verifiable. In furtherance of the policy to ensure nuclear security, the President will work with other countries and the International Atomic Energy Agency to upgrade security measures for nuclear weapons and materials, provide financial and technical assistance where needed, and collaborate with other governments to sustain security upgrades. The President aims to collaborate with other countries to establish effective nuclear security rules worldwide, including implementing a regulatory design-basis threat model to counter threats from terrorists and criminals. Authorization of appropriations for fiscal year 2008 includes $50,000,000 for increasing international participation in converting nuclear facilities to low enriched uranium and removing highly enriched uranium from these facilities.
